title: Fiona Phillips: Anxiety, lies, misery... is this being happy?
text:

Apparently we’re all becoming happier. How do I know? Because the Office for National Statistics says we are. Have you noticed a new happiness vibe? Can’t say I have to be honest.

Have you found yourself becoming progressively chucklesome over the past year? Are the occupants of the No 73 bus suddenly full of joie de vivre and bonhomie as they draw closer to work each morning?

Nah, ’fraid not. And, if you don’t mind, I won’t have the ONS telling me I’m happy, when I’m mostly not. If you must know, I’m mostly anxious and low-level depressed, with an overriding sense of ‘is this IT?’ Is this REALLY IT? Is this what our kids will inherit?

I worry about the longevity of our disposable planet as the world grows ever more madder and crowded.

Regular journeys on the London Underground – amazing, efficient and very useful, though it is – will convince one, if one needs convincing, that the world is now entirely populated by rude, selfish people, who think nothing of jostling other human beings out of the way as they head for their squeezed-in, stand-up journey to toil at a desk.

I’m fearful of the consequences of the almighty, totally unnecessary Brexit wrench.

And scared stiff of another term of Boris at the helm of this once great, now fractured, country.

I’m wondering how, in one of the most worrisome times since the end of the Second World War, the Office for National Statistics has come to the conclusion that during this unstable, uncertain, uncalled for period in history – characterised by its raft of lies, splits and divisions and the creation of an unnecessary, messy, huge scar on our relationship with our European allies – we are “becoming happier” with our lot.

During a time in our history in which anxiety levels have risen in line with the absurdity of events, how can these anxiety levels be down? Nearly everyone I know, including my sons and my stoic, unflappable husband, have experienced horrible, prohibitive anxiety.

One can only conclude, then, that the Office for National Statistics has been talking to robots rather than us flustered-beyond-coping, stressed-out human beings.
